## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**AI Assistant:**
Hey there! I'm here to assist you in understanding Verus. What's on your mind today?

**User:**
I'm trying to understand the `definecurrency` command in Verus. What's its purpose?

**AI Assistant:**
The `definecurrency` command is used to define a new PBaaS blockchain and its properties, such as its name, options, currencies, conversions, eras, notaries, nodes, and gateway converter settings. It's a powerful tool for creating a customized blockchain within the Verus ecosystem.

**User:**
That sounds complex. What are the components of a PBaaS blockchain definition in Verus?

**AI Assistant:**
A PBaaS blockchain definition in Verus consists of several components, including:

1. `name`: the name of the chain
2. `options`: an integer that defines the chain's properties
3. `currencies`: an array of currency tickers that the chain's native currency can be converted into
4. `conversions`: an array of conversion ratios between the chain's native currency and each currency on the chain
5. `eras`: an array of objects that define the block reward, reward decay, halving, and end of each era in the chain's lifecycle
6. `notaries`: an array of VerusIDs that will serve as notaries on the chain
7. `minnotariesconfirm`: an integer that specifies the minimum number of notaries needed to confirm a block
8. `nodes`: an array of objects that describe the network addresses of the nodes on the chain, as well as their IDs
9. `gatewayconvertername`: the name of the bridge converter
10. `gatewayconverterissuance`: the initial issuance of the bridge converter

These components work together to define the properties and behavior of your PBaaS blockchain.

**User:**
That's a lot to take in. Are there any limitations I should be aware of when creating a currency from an ID in Verus?

**AI Assistant:**
One important limitation to be aware of is that you will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. This is because using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. It is generally not recommended to create an ID with an i-address as its name, as it can cause problems in various cases and will not be supported for creating currencies.

So, when creating a currency from an ID, make sure to choose a name that doesn't conflict with an i-address. Do you have any more questions about PBaaS or currency creation in Verus?
What is the purpose of the `definecurrency` command in Verus?
The `definecurrency` command is used to define a new PBaaS blockchain and its properties, such as its name, options, currencies, conversions, eras, notaries, nodes, and gateway converter settings.

### Defining a PBaaS blockchain ```json  {   "name": "PBaaSChain",   "options": 264,   "currencies": [    "VRSCTEST"   ],   "conversions": [    1   ],   "eras": [    {     "reward": 1200000000,     "decay": 0,     "halving": 0,     "eraend": 0    }   ],   "notaries": [    "Notary1@",    "Notary2@",    "Notary3@",   ],   "minnotariesconfirm": 2,   "nodes": [    {     "networkaddress": "111.111.111.111:10000",     "nodeidentity": "Node1@"    },    {     "networkaddress": "111.111.111.112:10000",     "nodeidentity": "Node2@"    }   ],   "gatewayconvertername": "Bridge",   "gatewayconverterissuance": 1000000  } ``` The bridge definition has overridable defaults ```json  {   "currencies": [    "VRSCTEST",    "PBaaSChain",    "USD"   ],   "initialcontributions": [    380228.12033701,    0,    1000000   ],   "initialsupply": 3000000  } ```Now pass those definitions to `definecurrency` ```json ./verus -chain=vrsctest definecurrency '{"name":"PBaaSChain","options":264,"currencies":["VRSCTEST"],"conversions":[1],"eras":[{"reward":1200000000,"decay":0,"halving":0,"eraend":0}],"notaries":["Notary1@","Notary2@","Notary3@"],"minnotariesconfirm":2,"nodes":[{"networkaddress":"111.111.111.111:10000","nodeidentity":"Node1@"},{"networkaddress":"111.111.111.112:10000","nodeidentity":"Node2@"}],"gatewayconvertername":"Bridge","gatewayconverterissuance":1000000}' '{"currencies":["VRSCTEST","PBaaSChain","USD"],"initialcontributions":[371747.20398827,0,1000000],"initialsupply":3000000}' ```### Limitations in multi-currency to be aware of: 1. (GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.
What are the components of a PBaaS blockchain definition in Verus?

6. `notaries`: an array of VerusIDs that will serve as notaries on the chain
7. `minnotariesconfirm`: an integer that specifies the minimum number of notaries needed to confirm a block
8. `nodes`: an array of objects that describe the network addresses of the nodes on the chain, as well as their IDs
9. `gatewayconvertername`: the name of the bridge converter
10. `gatewayconverterissuance`: the initial issuance of the bridge converter

(GUI and CLI) You will not be able to make a currency from an ID that has a properly encoded i-address as its actual name, not its calculated ID. Generally, the advice is “don’t do that”. Using an i-address when referring to a currency will only be interpreted as referring to the currency or identity which has that i-address calculated based on its name registration. As a general rule, making an ID with an i-address as its name is not prevented by the protocol, but will cause problems whenever an i-address or name may be used (many cases) and will not be supported for creating currencies. To reduce any potential for user confusion, even though the naming system provides will also be expanding the set of characters that will not be allowed for currency registrations.
